Is wa. there a province, is there in any part of the empire a single camp, which he has not defiled with blood? This, he will tell you, is a reform of the army. In his language, murder is a legal remedy: what all good men agree to call a deed of barbarity, passes with him for a cor- rection of abuses. Under specious names he confounds the nature of things: cruelty is justice, avarice is ceconomy, and massaere is military dis* ciphne. Since the death of Nero not more than seven months have elapsed; and, in that time, Icejus his freedman^ has amassed, by plunder, more enor- mous wealth than the Polycleti (&), the Vatinii, the Elii, and the Haloti were able to do in the whole course of that emperors reign. Even Titus Vinius, if he himself had seized the empire, would have had the grace to blush at such enormities; nor should we have groan- ed under such a load of oppression.
